State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China Graphical abstract Several multifunctional monocomponent zinc halide-based ionic liquids were facilely prepared and exhibited excellent catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides under solvent and co-catalyst free conditions. Multifunctional monocomponent zinc halide-based ionic liquids, amidinothiourea-ZnI2 (ATUI) and N-phenylthiourea-ZnI2 (NTUI), were facilely developed as homogeneous catalysts for efficient conversion of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates. On account of synergistic effects of multifunctional components in ATUI, the propylene carbonate yield could reach 95% under 110 °C, 1.0 MPa, 4.0 h or even mild conditions. There was a slight decrease of propylene carbonate yield because of the loss of ATUI during the reuse process. Additionally, the universality of ATUI was also studied to other terminal epoxides. Meanwhile, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed where the synergistic effects involving cation structure and halogen anion of ATUI guarantee the cycloaddition reaction to proceed effectively under solvent and co-catalyst free condition. Finally, reaction kinetics were undertaken to compare the catalytic efficiency of ATUI and NTUI so as to compare the catalytic activity of different numbers of hydrogen bond donor in amidinothiourea and N-phenylthiourea. Keywords Eutectic-based ionic liquid CO2 cycloaddition Epoxide Cyclic carbonate 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide, one of the undesired greenhouse effect gases, is an abundant, inexpensive, and non-toxic renewable C1 resource and so the development of an efficient catalytic process for CO2 transformation into value-added products is a challenging and practically important task [1]. The 100% atom-economic cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides for producing the five-membered cyclic carbonates is one of the most promising endeavors in the CO2 conversion fields (Scheme 1 ) [2]. The cyclic carbonates products find wide potential applications as polar aprotic solvents, electrolytes for lithium-ion batteries, intermediates in the manufacture of fine chemicals [3], constituents of oils and raw materials in the synthesis of polycarbonates [4]. Recently, an immense number of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalytic systems have been developed for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides, including metal-oxides [5,6], alkali metal salts [7], metal–salen complexes [8,9], organic bases [10,11], metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [12–14], plentiful ionic liquids [15–17], and modified molecular sieves [18,19]. Among these catalysts, ionic liquids (ILs) are widely studied because of their high thermal stability and high-activity. However, common ionic liquids are limited by the complicated synthesis process, requirement of costly raw materials, harsh experimental conditions [20]. Therefore, eutectic-based ionic liquids (EILs), which are low cost, environmental friendliness, simple operation and high performances, have received renewed interests [21]. For example, it has been reported that choline chloride-glycerol as solvent for desulfurization [22], N-methyl-pyrrolidone-metal halide as extractant for fuel desulfurization [23], amides/diols-ZnCl2 were used in electro-deposition [24], urea-choline chloride for CO2 capture [25], and urea-metal halide as catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition reaction [26]. However, those reported EILs were synthesized by heating under 80 °C or 100 °C for a period of time, herein, a series of zinc halide-based ionic liquids (ZHILs) were developed and facilely synthesized at room temperature and then applications in cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to terminal epoxides. The cycloaddition reactions of CO2 to terminal epoxides catalyzed by ZHILs, such as amidinothiourea-ZnI2 (ATUI) and N-phenylthiourea-ZnI2 (NTUI), were investigated thoroughly, including the screening of different ZHILs, reaction temperature, CO2 pressure and reaction time. All cycloaddition reactions were conducted under solvent- and co-catalyst free conditions. It is worth mentioning that those ZHILs exhibited excellent multifunctional and synergetic effects for CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides even under mild reaction conditions. Then, a possible reaction mechanism was proposed, and the dynamic model was also given to discuss the reaction activation energy of cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by ATUI and NTUI so as to compare the catalytic activity of different numbers of hydrogen bond donor in the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and instruments Amidinothiourea (ATU, 98%), N-phenylthiourea (NTU, 98%), all anhydrous ZnCl2 (≥98.0%), ZnBr2 (≥98.0%) and ZnI2 (≥98.0%) and epoxides were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Co.. Ethyl alcohol (≥99.7%) was purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. Carbon dioxide with 99.99% purity was provided from Harbin Liming Industrial gases Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as it received without further purification. Melting points measurement was performed on a BÜCHI melting point B-540 apparatus. 1H NMR spectra were obtained on Bruker 400 M nuclear resonance spectrometer. FT-IR spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR Spectrometer by using anhydrous KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves were obtained using NETZSCH STA449F3 simultaneous thermogravimetric analyzer under the conditions of 30–300 °C. ICP-AES measurement was conducted by PerkinElmer ICP-OES Optima 8300 instrument. EA was conducted on Vario MICRO cube CHN analyzer. GC analyses were performed on an Agilent GC-7890A equipped with capillary column (Agilent 19091J-413) and a flame ionization detector. 2.2 The synthesis process of ZHILs The preparation of six kinds of zinc halide-based ionic liquids (ZHILs) was as follows, in a typical run, ATU and ZnI2 at mole ratio 2:1 (0.2 mmol: 0.1 mmol) were added into a beaker equipped with a magnetic stir bar, and 50 mL ethyl alcohol was added with stirring for 4 h. Thereafter, the ethyl alcohol was removed by rotary evaporation, the sticky remaining was named as ATUI (Named by the logogram of thiourea derivatives and halide). In order to prevent the effect of light, all synthesis processes were conducted in the light avoided condition. The difference of other ZHILs is that ATU was replaced by NTU or ZnI2 was replaced by ZnBr2 or ZnCl2. Besides, ATUI was synthesized by traditional method [26] to illuminate the action of solvent alcohol. Typically, 0.2 mmol ATU and 0.1 mmol ZnI2 were added to a beaker equipped with a magnetic stirrer. Thereafter, the beaker was stirred for 48 h under 100 °C, then a homogeneous liquid was obtained and marked as ATUI-solventless. 2.3 Catalytic procedure for CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides In a typical run, 0.1 g ATUI was added into a 50 mL high pressure stainless-steel autoclave that equipped with a magnetic stirring bar. Then 34.5 mmol propylene epoxide (PO) was added, the autoclave was heated to a preset temperature of 100 °C. At the fixed reaction temperature, CO2 was then introduced to 2 MPa and heated for a period of time. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature in ice-water bath, and the remaining CO2 was depressurized slowly. The product was diluted with ethyl acetate and analyzed on GC. Then, the ethyl acetate solvent was separated by rotary evaporation, and the remaining catalyst was reused for the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization In order to illuminate the action of solvent alcohol in the synthesis of ATUI IL, FT-IR was employed to compare the differences between ATUI and ATUI-solventless, and the results were given in Fig. 1 . There was no difference between ATUI and ATUI-solventless, which indicated alcohol could accelerate the formation of ATUI, thus, decrease reaction temperature and reaction time. Therefore, alcohol solvent was employed in the synthesis of ATUI. In order to confirm the possible molar ratio of thiourea derivatives and zinc halides, a series of amidinothiourea-ZnI2 and N-phenylthiourea-ZnI2 with different molar ratios were facilely synthesized and their melting points were given in Fig. 2 . In all corresponding products, only ATU-ZnI2 (ZnI2 molar ratio 20%), NTU-ZnI2 (ZnI2 molar ratio 20%) and ATU-ZnI2 (ZnI2 molar ratio 25%) were solid states at room temperature, others were liquids. In consideration of all the catalysts were liquid, and ATU is cheaper than ZnI2, molar ratio of thiourea derivative and ZnI2 was set as 2:1. In order to clarify the molar ratio of ATU and ZnI2 in the final ATUI catalyst, the content of Zn in ATUI was analyzed on ICP-AES, 11.33% Zn mass content was detected, close to the theoretical Zn 11.77% in the ATUI catalyst. And the content of N in ATUI was analyzed on EA, 20.18% N mass content was detected, close to the theoretical N 20.16% in ATUI. Thus, the molar ratio of ATU and ZnI2 in the final obtained ATUI IL was at 2:1. Because of the metal salts were all anhydrous, ATUI could be regarded as type I eutectic IL [25]. 1H NMR spectra was adopted to analyze the structure of ATUI and NTUI, the results were shown in Fig. 3 . Compared with ATU, there were chemical shifts to low-field of ATUI, which may be caused by electron-withdrawing effect of Lewis acid Zn2+ [27]. There are no obviously chemical shifts observed in NTU and NTUI, which may be caused by the large conjugative effect of NTU molecule except the terminal primary amine [28]. Therefore, the possible structures of ZHILs were given in Scheme 2 . ATU: 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 7.16 (s, 1 H), 7.07 (s, 1 H) ATUI: 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 7.76 (s, 1 H), 7.52 (s, 1 H) NTU: 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.68 (s, 1 H), 7.45–7.37 (m, 2 H), 7.36–7.28 (m, 2 H), 7.16–7.07 (m, 1 H) NTUI: 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.69 (s, 1 H), 7.46–7.35 (m, 2 H), 7.31 (t, J =7.9 Hz, 2 H), 7.17–7.03 (m, 1 H) FT-IR and thermogravimetric analysis were further employed to characterize ATUI and NTUI, as shown in Fig. 4 . After the formation of Zn–N bond in ATUI, the peak around 3300 cm−1 was integrated to a broad peak, meanwhile, the 440 cm−1 peak also indicated the formation of Zn–N [29]. (Fig. 4A) The shift of 1530 cm−1 to 1520 cm−1 might be attributed to the weakened vibration of ATU molecular and the new peak at 2201 cm−1 may be ascribed to the resonance of Zn–N–C [30], which means the coordination bond has been created between ATU and Zn2+. Fig. 4B shows the FT-IR of NTU and NTUI, after the formation of Zn–N, the peak around 3300 cm−1 of NTUI might be caused by the coupling of –NH and –NH2 of NTU. The peak of NTU at 490 cm−1 was ascribed to the out-of-plane vibration of CN, which bonded to phenyl. [31] The broad peak around 550 cm−1 was caused by the coupling of the vibration of new formed ZnN bond and the peak of 490 cm−1 [32]. The peak of 2240 cm−1 may be ascribed to the resonance of ZnNC bond, the shift compared to ATUI might be caused by the large conjugative effect of NTU [33]. The results of FT-IR combined with 1H NMR also indicated the structure of ATUI. Fig. 4C shows the TG curves of ATUI and NTUI, the weight loss of ATUI starts at 134 °C obviously, meanwhile, NTUI starts to lose weight at 190 °C, hence, ATUI and NTUI could accomplish catalytic process at 110 °C. 3.2 Screening of catalysts The catalytic activity of six kinds of ZHILs was probed on the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to propylene epoxide (PO), the results are demonstrated in Table 1 . When ZnI2 acted as catalyst only, trace propylene carbonate (PC) was produced (Entry 1), 13% PC yield was obtained when ATU was added only (Entry 2). Similarly, NTU could produce trace PC (Entry 6). While, ZHILs could improve catalytic activities for PC synthesis to different degrees (Entries 3–4 and 7–8). However, when ZnCl2 combined with ATU or NTU, the PC yield hardly promoted, which was possibly because of the low nucleophilicity of Cl–. ATUI exhibited the excellent PC yield among all ZHILs. On the basis of ATUX or NTUX (X = I–, Br–, Cl–) alone, the catalytic activity was significantly influenced by the nucleophilicity of halide in the order of I– > Br– > Cl– (Entries 3–5 and 7–9), similar results were reported [34,35]. ATUBr possessed better catalytic activities than NTUBr (Entries 4, 8), possibly because ATU has more hydrogen bond donor than NTU, which would accelerate the cycloaddition reaction of PO and CO2 and will be discussed later. Other corresponding ZHILs (ATUI and NTUI, ATUCl and NTUCl) showed similar catalytic abilities, possibly because ZnX2 played a more important role than ATU or NTU for the cycloaddition reaction. When ATU and ZnI2 were mixed mechanically, 85% PC yield was achieved (Entry 10). Besides, the catalytic activity of ATUI is promoted compared with mechanical ATU/ZnI2 catalysts (Entries 3 and 10). Hence, monocomponent ATUI was attracted as the feasible candidate catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 to PO. 3.3 The optimization of reaction parameters for CO2 cycloaddition reaction The influence of reaction temperature on PC yield and selectivity is shown in Fig. 5 A. Expectedly, the cycloaddition reaction is sensitive to reaction temperature, the catalytic activity increased with elevated temperature from 70 °C to 120 °C, which was ascribed to more effective collisions between the active species in the catalyst and the substrates at high temperature [36]. Hence, 110 °C might be the suitable reaction temperature. Fig. 5B shows the effects of CO2 pressure on the cycloaddition reaction, the PC yield was sensitive to the CO2 pressure below 1.0 MPa, and when the pressure increased to 1.5 MPa, the PC yield achieved 96%. From 1.5 to 2.5 MPa, the CO2 pressure had little effect on the PC yield and selectivity, which was resulted from the concentration variations in the reactants of PO and CO2 in the phase of CO2-PO [37]. Therefore, 1.0 MPa preferred to be a suitable reaction pressure. In addition, the relationship between the catalytic activity and reaction time is given in Fig. 5C. The PC yield increased rapidly with reaction time and the PC yield reached an excellent value of 95% after 4.0 h. Hence, the cycloaddition reaction was performed on the optimum condition of 110 °C, 1.0 MPa, 4.0 h to investigate the reusability and general applicability of ATUI. Satisfactorily, the selectivity of PC product retained at an excellent value invariably. 3.4 Reusability of ATUI catalyst The recyclability of ATUI catalyst is a crucial factor in practical application. After each run, the ethyl acetate solvent was separated by rotary evaporation, and the remaining catalyst was reused for the next run, as shown in Fig. 6 A. Due to the slight loss of ATUI and slight leaching of Zn during the reaction or recycle process, 20 mg fresh ATUI was added in the 6th cycle, PC yield could retain at 93%. ICP-AES, EA and FT-IR were adopted to analyze the structure of the reused ATUI. ICP-AES result showed that the Zn mass content was reduced to 10.32% in the spent ATUI after five recycles from 11.33% of the fresh ATUI catalyst. And EA result showed that N mass content was increased from 20.18% to 20.22% after five recycles, which also indicated the slight leaching of Zn. Thus, the molar ratio of ATU to ZnI2 in the reused catalyst was slightly changed after five cycles, which also affected the catalytic recyclability. Moreover, in Fig. 6B, no obvious difference in FT-IR spectra between the reused and fresh ATUI catalysts was observed during 4000 cm−1 -1750 cm-1. And the peak of 1670 cm-1 in the spent catalyst might be caused by the coupling of 1700 cm-1 (imine bond stretch in decomposed ATU) and 1630 cm-1 (amino asymmetric deformation in ATUI) [38]. The peak of 1360 cm-1 in the spent catalyst was resulted from the coupling of 1420 cm−1 in the decomposed ATU and 1340 cm−1 in the fresh ATUI catalyst. The peak of 1265 cm-1 in the spent catalyst was resulted from the coupling of 1290 cm−1 in the residual decomposed ATU and 1240 cm−1 in ATUI catalyst. These changes were resulted from the intermolecular structural variability of ATUI during the catalytic reaction process [39]. These changes in FT-IR also indirectly indicated the slight leaching of Zn during the recycles. Satisfactorily, the catalytic activity of ATUI decreased from 95% to 80% after five cycles. 3.5 Catalytic activity towards other epoxides In order to study the general applicability of ATUI catalyst under the mild reaction conditions, 90 °C was chosen to be another reaction temperature at the sacrifice of reaction time (6 h). As shown in Table 2 , the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with different substituent terminal epoxides proceeded efficiently. Propylene epoxide, epichlorohydrin and epoxybutane could be converted to the corresponding products with high yields and excellent selectivities (Entries 1–3). However, the conversion activities of styrene oxide, allyl glycidyl ether and butyl glycidyl ether were lower than PO, which were resulted from their steric hindrance of side-chains, preventing the nucleophilic attack of I− to C atom of epoxides (Entries 4–6) [19,40]. Cyclohexene oxide exhibited the lowest yield among all the epoxides because of the two rings in substituent, which seriously restricted the attack of nucleophilic reagent to epoxide and subsequent ring-opening of epoxide (Entry 7). 3.6 Plausible reaction mechanism It has been proved that hydrogen bond can be formed between the oxygen atom of epoxides and the hydrogen atom of amine [2], which could lead to the polarization of the CO bond of PO [35], sequentially, accelerating the ring-opening reaction of epoxides. Additionally, metal zinc was able to form zinc-epoxide adduct with substrate epoxide [41,42], which could also facilitate the ring-opening reaction. Meanwhile, nucleophilic group I– attacked the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of activated epoxide [2,43,44]. Combined with our experimental results, a feasible reaction mechanism was presented in Scheme 3 . Initially, Lewis acid Zn2+ cooperated with the amino of ATUI would coordinate with the oxygen atom of epoxides, which could lead to the formation of hydrogen bond and zinc-epoxide adduct (Step 1). Secondly, the nucleophilic I– attacked to less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of activated epoxide so as to promote the ring-opening of terminal epoxide to form an oxyanion intermediate (Step 2). Because of the better nucleophilic property, I–had the higher catalytic activity than Br– and Cl–, thus, I– could promote the ring-opening reaction most efficiently, which was generally recognized as the rate-determining step for the whole CO2 cycloaddition reaction [45]. And then, the oxyanion intermediate would interact with the subsequent CO2 (Step 3). Ultimately, intramolecular ring-closure process occurred and the cyclic carbonate product was obtained, the catalyst ATUI was regenerated at the same time (Step 4). Hence, CO2 cycloaddition reaction was facilitated by ATUI, which provided with multifunctional groups of Lewis acid Zn and –NH2 as hydrogen bond donor to facilitate the synergetic effects on cycloaddition reaction. Satisfactorily, the cycloaddition reaction was processed under cocatalyst- and solvent-free condition. 3.7 Calculation of activation energy A dynamic model was developed to discuss the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and propylene epoxide over ATUI and NTUI so as to illucidate the effects of substitutes of ATU and NTU on catalytic activity, where ATU possesses more hydrogen bond donor. Actually, there were two steps in the cycloaddition reaction, and the probable elementary reaction rate equations can be proposed as follow: [46] (1) P O + C a t . k 1 ⇌ k 2 I n t e r m e d i a t e (2) I n t e r m e d i a t e + C O 2 k 3 → P C + C a t . k1 , k2 and k3 represent reaction rate constants. Then, assuming the reaction is at pseudosteady state, the rate of PC formation was described as Eq. (3) [47]. (3) d [ P C ] d t = - d P O d t = k o b s [ P O ] d[PC] showsthe PC concentration at a particular reaction time, t: reaction time, kobs exhibits the observed pseudo-first-order rate constant, [PO] is the remaining concentration of PO at t moment in the reaction system. Integrating Eq. (3) yielded Eq. (4): (4) ln 1 P O = k o b s t According to Eq. (4), the plot of –ln([PO]) versus time was given in Fig. 7 , the linear curves indicated the reaction order was 1 [48], meanwhile, the kobs at different temperature and Arrhenius plots could be obtained (Fig. 7C). According to Arrhenius plots, activation energy and pre-exponential factor could be calculated in Table 3 . A: the pre-exponential factor The activation energies are 24.1 kJ·mol−1 and 31.7 kJ·mol−1 for ATUI and NTUI, respectively, coming from the numbers of hydrogen bond donor in catalysts. The reduced activation energy was resulted that ATU possessed more hydrogen bond donors than NTU, which made great contributions to reduce the activation energy for the cycloaddition reaction CO2 to cyclic carbonates. 4 Conclusion The multifunctional monocomponent zinc halide-based ionic liquids were facilely synthesized and used as efficient catalyst for CO2 conversion into cyclic carbonates under solvent and co-catalyst free conditions. Amidinothiourea-ZnI2 (ATUI) showed the best catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition to PO, and also exhibited outstanding reusability and catalytic activity over other cycloaddition reactions of CO2 to terminal epoxides. Meanwhile, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed where the synergistic effects involving cation structure and halogen anion of ATUI guaranteed the cycloaddition reaction to proceed effectively. Ultimately, the detection of activation energy over ATUI and NTUI was given to illuminate that hydrogen bond donor could effectively promote the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. coredata.dc:description: Multifunctional monocomponent zinc halide-based ionic liquids, amidinothiourea-ZnI2 (ATUI) and N-phenylthiourea-ZnI2 (NTUI), were facilely developed as homogeneous catalysts for efficient conversion of CO2 with epoxides to cyclic carbonates. On account of synergistic effects of multifunctional components in ATUI, the propylene carbonate yield could reach 95% under 110 °C, 1.0 MPa, 4.0 h or even mild conditions. There was a slight decrease of propylene carbonate yield because of the loss of ATUI during the reuse process. Additionally, the universality of ATUI was also studied to other terminal epoxides. Meanwhile, a plausible reaction mechanism was proposed where the synergistic effects involving cation structure and halogen anion of ATUI guarantee the cycloaddition reaction to proceed effectively under solvent and co-catalyst free condition. Finally, reaction kinetics were undertaken to compare the catalytic efficiency of ATUI and NTUI so as to compare the catalytic activity of different numbers of hydrogen bond donor in amidinothiourea and N-phenylthiourea.
coredata.dc:title: Facile synthesis of zinc halide-based ionic liquid for efficient conversion of carbon dioxide to cyclic carbonates
